props.synopsis: More than 1,300 cars were stolen across the Northern Territory last year, and police say social media is fuelling the issue.

title.children: Ram raids and crime sprees in stolen cars: NT’s 'massive' car theft problem

image.altText: Man wearing a beanie and black t-shirt sings passionately into a microphone. a woman with curly hair smiles next to him

props.synopsis: Controversial senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price could become the next Minister for Indigenous Australians. She says tragedy and trauma shaped her views.

title.children: 'I was partying hard': Senator Jacinta Price reveals MDMA spiral

props.synopsis: An analysis of data by the ABC shows 69 women were killed in instances of gendered violence last year in Australia. All but 10 were killed by someone known to them.

title.children: A national shame: The data behind the killing of women in Australia

image.altText: Anthony Alabanese in a wide brimmed hat looks toward the camera with a woman out of the focus in the foreground

props.synopsis: Whichever party wins government at the upcoming federal election, the heightened focus on the Northern Territory in the lead-up is welcome proof its challenging issues aren’t just being swept under the rug.

title.children: Albanese and Dutton promise big for the NT, with one major caveat

image.altText: Police officer runs to make arrest in bush

props.synopsis: Queensland Police have charged three people with a litany of offences against representatives from space company Equatorial Launch Australia, including deprivation of liberty, threats and assault.

title.children: 'Dig a hole': Bush campers allegedly threaten space crew at knifepoint

image.altText: A red dirt road amongst a dry cattle station with dying shrubs

props.synopsis: Residents in the hottest parts of Australia say the extreme weather is making it impossible to work outdoors safely during the day, as thirsty camels create an additional challenge for cattle stations.

title.children: Outback temperatures too hot for electronics as residents 'try to survive'

image.altText: A tall fence with razor wire attached at the bottom and top. Blue sky and some jail buildings in the background.

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory government is set to introduce legislation next week to enable Corrections to source prison guards from private companies and interstate, as inmate numbers reach a new record.

title.children: Private prison guards to help staff NT jails as inmate numbers surge

image.altText: NT Chief Minister Lia Finocchiaro sitting inside a room and looking serious.

props.synopsis: As Lia Finocchiaro heads into her first full year as the Northern Territory's chief minister, she's promised "the end of this year will look very different to now".

title.children: Crime and economy the centre of NT chief minister’s ‘year of action’

image.altText: A man stands on stage in front of a crowd with his hands in the air clapping.

props.synopsis: They sell themselves on unlocking the secrets to personal, spiritual and financial success. But some life coaches are using a technique known as neuro-linguistic programming to recruit followers and make millions.

title.children: The pseudoscience pushed by life coaches as a ticket to financial success

image.altText: Samantha Kerr walks past an ABC journalist who is holding a microphone in front of her

props.synopsis: The case against Sam Kerr comes down to what she said to Constable Stephen Lovell, but the court has spent a lot of time focusing on what happened in the hours leading up to that moment.

title.children: A lot happened the night Sam Kerr called a policeman 'stupid and white'

image.altText: A blurry image of people queueing to enter a Centrelink office to apply for unemployment benefits.

props.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton suggests $24 billion could be saved if 36,000 public service jobs added by the Albanese government were cut. Thousands of those added have been in agencies critical to national security and service delivery.

title.children: Defence, Centrelink roles among the '36,000' added jobs in Dutton's crosshairs

image.altText: Three images in a composite including a man in glasses, an man with orange makeup and another man in glasses

props.synopsis: Foreign events, including war in Gaza and Donald Trump's return to office, are shaking up the political status quo and up-ending Australia's imminent election contest in ways politicians are scrambling to understand.

title.children: When the Greens and Barnaby Joyce agree, you know politics as we know it is in chaos

image.altText: The skyline of Auckland

props.synopsis: Australia's and New Zealand's central banks have used different strategies to kill inflation. New Zealand's now in recession, and Australia isn't. Can Australia pull it off?

title.children: Inflation has fallen in Australia and NZ, but which is faring better?

image.altText: A rugby player in a jersey standing next to a woman on a football field for a photo.

props.synopsis: Known as a "gentle giant" among his school and local rugby club in Sydney's west, Jordan Mailata is gearing up for his second Super Bowl. And his community couldn't be more excited.

title.children: Sydney 'gentle giant' a hero back home ahead of playing in Super Bowl

image.altText: A middle-aged man holding a coffee cup walks in a rich-looking building.

props.synopsis: US District Court Judge Paul Engelmayer cited the risk that sensitive data could be improperly disclosed in handing down his decision, which also included an order for those barred from accessing the systems to destroy any data they had previously collected.

title.children: US judge temporarily blocks Elon Musk's DOGE from accessing payment systems

image.altText: A person in foreground blurry points to scarce snow on mountain top.

props.synopsis: Glaciers across the Himalayas are melting at an unprecedented rate, threatening the water supply of rural villages living along the ancient mountain range.

title.children: Himalayan villages face a water crisis as the world's 'third pole' melts

image.altText: A policeman and ute standing in front of a temporary bridge

props.synopsis: A reprieve from heavy rainfall in north Queensland is expected to be short-lived, with more substantial falls and severe thunderstorms forecast for already-soaked areas.

title.children: North Qld communities record highest ever monthly rainfall in eight days

image.altText: Police cars at the scene

props.synopsis: A woman has died and another remains in a serious condition after a lightning strike hit a tree south of Sydney.

title.children: Sydney woman dies after tree explodes following lightning strike

props.synopsis: Around-the-clock coverage of news events as they break, at home and abroad.

title.children: Watch: News Channel

image.altText: Jacinta Allan looks serious at an outdoor press conference.

props.synopsis: A major swing against Labor in the Werribee by-election and a victory for the Liberal Party in Prahran may be a major warning for the Allan government.

title.children: After the Super Saturday of by-elections, alarm bells are ringing for Labor

image.altText: an execution chamber featuring a gurney with straps seen through a doorway

props.synopsis: Two men in Texas are sentenced to death for murdering their children — for one of them, it is already too late. For the other, the clock is ticking.

title.children: Two Texas fathers are sentenced to death, but questions linger

image.altText: A middle aged white woman with limb difference. She has curly hair and is standing in a kitchen smiling

props.synopsis: Answering curious questions from kids about disability can be tricky. Here's how three people with lived experience say you should go about it.

title.children: 'Mum, what's wrong with her?': How to answer kids' questions about disability

image.altText: Black writing on a white piece of paper with blue reflections

props.synopsis: There are concerns many people do not realise they are eligible for the discounts and so do not ask for them.

title.children: More than $100m in concessions on power bills going unclaimed

image.altText: Dimuth Karunaratne, Nathan Lyon and Steve Smith.

props.synopsis: Steve Smith continues to be superhuman in the field after an Australian collapse, as Sri Lanka's Dimuth Karunaratne says his final goodbye to Test cricket. Here are the quick hits from day three of the second Test.

title.children: Quick hits: Smith's freakish grab and a Sri Lankan great's final farewell

image.altText: A photo of Clancy Lester holding a net. He's standing alongside three Indigenous rangers who are also holding nets.

props.synopsis: A 23-year-old ecologist known as "The Bee Man" is on a mission to conserve solitary pollinators by building them structures where they can nest — and he's urging others to do the same.

title.children: Native bees are under threat — but building them 'hotels' can help

image.altText: A dark cloudy background with golden dollar signs and a white and rainbow unicorn in the foreground

props.synopsis: The increase of unicorn startups in Australia, which have a valuation of $1 billion, has increased according to market analyst, with separate figures echoing a rise of a financially-healthy tech sector in the country.

title.children: Australia's unicorn businesses earning billions and flourishing

image.altText: A red sedan, with a bent out of place bonnet smashed in from impact at the centre. Car doors open.

props.synopsis: More than 1,300 cars were stolen across the Northern Territory last year, and police say social media is fuelling the issue.

title.children: Ram raids and crime sprees in stolen cars: NT’s 'massive' car theft problem

image.altText: Various contraceptive medications and devices, like the pill, an IUD and condoms

props.synopsis: The election pitch also includes new measures for women in menopause, including efforts to lift support and care provided by GPs.

title.children: Labor pledges $573 million for women's health, including long-term contraceptives

image.altText: Hard Quiz host Tom Gleeson with his eyebrows raised and mouth open. The Hard Quiz logo is in the top right corner

props.synopsis: It's another week and a new chance to prove yourself. Let's play, HARD!

title.children: Have you got what it takes to pass Hard Quiz?

image.altText: Eastern brown snake beside a stone wall.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of snakes are moved from backyards, inside homes and other urban areas into reserves and bushland around Canberra each year — but until now, little has been known about what happens to snakes after they’re released.

title.children: Snakes become 'very disoriented', lose weight and get sick when relocated

image.altText: A young woman is sad and offended by her partner and is sittign with her body turned away from him on the couch.

props.synopsis: Yasmina Elmerkaoui can't recall exactly when she first came across the concept of the "roommate phase" online, but she quickly put together the pieces and realised it was something she had experienced.

title.children: Are you and your partner in the 'roommate phase'?

image.altText: Mid shot of two adult people, one younger and one older, standing in front of an Olympic pool. They are smiling at eachother.

props.synopsis: Admitting you can't swim in a nation girt by sea can be embarrassing. Learning to swim as an adult is difficult, but it's far from impossible. Here's where to start.

title.children: I'm an adult who can't swim. This is what I learned after a summer of lessons

image.altText: A woman sits on stage talking into a microphone.

props.synopsis: Despite being banned, beauty products with harmful ingredients are widely available in Indonesia. These women raise the alarm on TikTok.

title.children: 'Didn't want to interact with anyone': The costs of mercury in cosmetics

image.altText: Aerial photograph of a paper mill

props.synopsis: The new owner of the Boyer mill in Tasmania's Derwent Valley says it will need to diversify its products to remain viable. The takeover has been welcomed by the state government and the local council.

title.children: Newsprint maker set to embark on new chapter as newspapers decline

image.altText: two country music artists hug

props.synopsis: Once the realm of regional heartlands like Tamworth and Gympie, country music has now hit the mainstream.

title.children: Country music's mainstream moment has arrived
